Caps ON.description: When caps lock is ON (Only for shortcuts)

Caps OFF.description: When caps lock is OFF (Only for shortcuts)

Left Button.description: Primary mouse button. Which physical button this corresponds to depends on system settings; by default it is the left button.

Right Button.description: Secondary mouse button. Which physical button this corresponds to depends on system settings; by default it is the right button.

XButton1.description: 4th mouse button. Typically performs the same function as Browser_Back.

XButton2.description: 5th mouse button. Typically performs the same function as Browser_Forward.

Wheel Down.description: Turn the wheel upward (away from you).

Wheel Left.description: Scroll to the left. These can be used as hotkeys with some (but not all) mice which have a second wheel or support tilting the wheel to either side. In some cases, software bundled with the mouse must instead be used to control this feature. Regardless of the particular mouse.

Wheel Right.description: Scroll to the rigt. These can be used as hotkeys with some (but not all) mice which have a second wheel or support tilting the wheel to either side. In some cases, software bundled with the mouse must instead be used to control this feature. Regardless of the particular mouse.

Scroll Lock.description: ScrollLock (scroll lock key). While Ctrl is held down, ScrollLock produces the key code of CtrlBreak, but can be differentiated from Pause by scan code (SC).

Apps Key.description: Menu. This is the key that invokes the right-click context menu.

Pause.description: Pause or Ctrl+NumLock. While Ctrl is held down, Pause produces the key code of CtrlBreak and NumLock produces Pause, so use CtrlBreak in hotkeys instead of Pause.

Help.description: Help. This probably doesn't exist on most keyboards. It's usually not the same as F1.

Sleep.description: Sleep. Note that the sleep key on some keyboards might not work with this.

Launch App1.description: Launch This PC (formerly My Computer or Computer)

Num Lock.description: NumLock (number lock key). While Ctrl is held down, NumLock produces the key code of Pause, so use Pause in hotkeys instead of NumLock.

VK_OEM_1.description: It can vary by keyboard. For the US ANSI keyboard , the Semiсolon and Colon key

VK_OEM_PLUS.description: For any country/region, the Equals and Plus key

VK_OEM_COMMA.description: For any country/region, the Comma and Less Than key

VK_OEM_MINUS.description: For any country/region, the Dash and Underscore key

VK_OEM_PERIOD.description: For any country/region, the Period and Greater Than key

VK_OEM_2.description: It can vary by keyboard. For the US ANSI keyboard, the Forward Slash and Question Mark key

VK_OEM_3.description: It can vary by keyboard. For the US ANSI keyboard, the Grave Accent and Tilde key

VK_OEM_4.description: It can vary by keyboard. For the US ANSI keyboard, the Left Brace key

VK_OEM_5.description: It can vary by keyboard. For the US ANSI keyboard, the Backslash and Pipe key

VK_OEM_6.description: It can vary by keyboard. For the US ANSI keyboard, the Right Brace key

VK_OEM_7.description: It can vary by keyboard. For the US ANSI keyboard, the Apostrophe and Double Quotation Mark key

VK_OEM_8.description: It can vary by keyboard. For the Canadian CSA keyboard, the Right Ctrl key

VK_OEM_102.description: It can vary by keyboard. For the European ISO keyboard, the Backslash and Pipe key

VK_PACKET.description: Used to pass Unicode characters as if they were keystrokes. The VK_PACKET key is the low word of a 32-bit Virtual Key value used for non-keyboard input methods. For more information, see Remark in KEYBDINPUT, SendInput, WM_KEYDOWN, and WM_KEYUP
